extracted_data.requirement: Adopt the International Standard ISO/IEC 27001:2005 as a Swiss Norm
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement mandates the organization to adopt the international standard ISO/IEC 27001:2005, which provides requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an information security management system.

controls.control: Establish, implement, maintain and continually improve an ISMS to ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information assets. This includes defining scope, establishing policies, implementing controls, conducting risk assessments, and reviewing the effectiveness of the system.

Develop, document, distribute, and maintain information security policies that define the organization's approach to managing information security. These policies should cover areas such as access controls, incident response, and data protection.

Regularly assess the risks to information assets and implement appropriate controls to mitigate those risks. This includes identifying potential threats, vulnerabilities, and impacts, as well as evaluating the likelihood and severity of each risk.

Develop and implement training programs to ensure that employees are aware of their responsibilities regarding information security. This includes training on topics such as password management, email security, and safe use of organizational resources.

Develop and implement an incident response plan to ensure that the organization can respond effectively to information security incidents. This includes defining roles and responsibilities, establishing procedures for investigating and containing incidents, and outlining steps for recovery and post-incident analysis.

Maintain an up-to-date inventory of all information assets, including hardware, software, data, and networks, to ensure their protection.

extracted_data.requirement: Clause 4.2: The organization shall appoint a member of the top management who would be responsible for information security.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that senior management is accountable for the overall information security within the organization.

controls.control: The organization shall appoint a senior executive as the Information Security Officer (ISO). The ISO will be responsible for overseeing and implementing the information security program, ensuring compliance with all relevant laws, regulations, and organizational policies.

controls.control_title: Define Information Security Roles and Responsibilities
controls.control: The organization shall clearly define the roles and responsibilities of all employees in relation to information security. This includes, but is not limited to, defining the role of the ISO, IT staff, data owners, and end-users.

The organization shall establish an Information Security Committee (ISC) to provide strategic direction for the information security program. The ISC should include representatives from all relevant departments and report directly to the Board of Directors.

The organization shall document the duties and responsibilities of the Information Security Officer in a job description. This document should be reviewed and updated regularly to ensure it remains current.

controls.control: Develop a comprehensive, written statement that outlines the boundaries of the Information Security Management System (ISMS). This should include all assets, processes, locations, and third parties involved in the organization's critical operations.

controls.control_title: Regularly review and update ISMS scope
controls.control: Establish a schedule for periodic reviews of the ISMS scope to ensure it remains accurate and relevant as the organization evolves. This may include adding new assets, processes, or locations, or removing those no longer in use.

extracted_data.requirement: Clause 4.4: The organization shall identify the legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements that are applicable to its information security.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement helps organizations to understand and comply with relevant laws, regulations, and contracts related to information security.

controls.control: Develop and maintain a comprehensive inventory of all applicable laws, regulations, and statutes that pertain to the organization's information security. This includes federal, state, and local laws.
Conduct regular reviews of industry-specific regulations and standards that apply to the organization's information security. This includes but is not limited to, HIPAA, GDPR, PCI DSS, etc.
Review all contracts and service level agreements (SLAs) for any information security-related obligations. Ensure that the organization is meeting these requirements and document any exceptions.

controls.control_title: Establish a Legal and Compliance Team
controls.control: Create a dedicated team responsible for monitoring changes in laws, regulations, and contractual obligations. This team should also be responsible for ensuring the organization's compliance with these requirements.

Conduct regular audits to ensure that the organization is in compliance with all identified legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements. Document findings and implement corrective actions as necessary.
Develop and deliver training programs to raise awareness about the organization's legal, regulatory, and contractual obligations. This should include regular refresher courses.

extracted_data.requirement: Clause 6.1: The organization shall develop and implement a risk assessment process.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement sets the foundation for managing risks within the ISMS.

controls.control: Form a dedicated team responsible for risk assessment, consisting of representatives from various departments and functional areas. This team should be equipped with the necessary skills and knowledge to identify, evaluate, and mitigate risks.

Create a comprehensive risk assessment framework that outlines the process for identifying, assessing, and prioritizing risks. The framework should include guidelines for risk categorization, risk analysis methods, and risk mitigation strategies.
Establish a schedule for conducting regular risk assessments. This could be quarterly, semi-annually, or annually, depending on the organization's risk profile and industry standards.

Maintain accurate records of all risk assessments, including the identified risks, their potential impact, likelihood, and risk mitigation strategies implemented. These documents should be easily accessible to relevant stakeholders.

Provide training to employees on the importance of risk assessment, their roles in the process, and how to identify potential risks. This could be through workshops, online modules, or on-the-job training.

controls.control: Create, maintain, and regularly update an Information Security Management System (ISMS) manual that outlines the organization's policies, procedures, and guidelines for managing information security. This document should include the scope of the ISMS, roles and responsibilities, risk assessment methodology, incident response plan, and continual improvement processes.

Designate a senior executive as the Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) or similar role responsible for overseeing the ISMS and ensuring its effective implementation, operation, monitoring, review, maintenance, and improvement.
Develop and implement policies, procedures, and guidelines based on the ISMS manual to ensure consistent application of information security controls across the organization.
Perform risk assessments regularly to identify, evaluate, and prioritize potential risks to the organization's information assets and implement appropriate controls to mitigate those risks.

Develop an incident response plan that outlines the steps to be taken in the event of a security breach or other information security incident. The plan should include roles and responsibilities, communication procedures, and steps for investigating, containing, and recovering from incidents.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Training and Awareness Programs
controls.control: Provide regular training and awareness programs to employees on information security best practices, policies, and procedures. This can help ensure that all employees understand their roles in maintaining the organization's information security.

extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement is essential for understanding what needs to be protected in an organization.

controls.control: Regularly update and maintain an accurate inventory of all organizational assets, including hardware, software, data, and intellectual property. This includes tracking asset location, ownership, and usage.

extracted_data.requirement: Protect sensitive information from unauthorized access.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement is important for maintaining privacy and preventing data breaches.

controls.control: Establish and enforce access control policies that limit system access to authorized personnel only. This includes setting up user accounts, passwords, and permissions according to the principle of least privilege.

Use encryption methods to protect sensitive data both at rest and in transit. This includes using strong encryption algorithms, secure key management, and proper implementation of encryption protocols.

Regularly audit access logs to detect any unauthorized access attempts or unusual activity. This includes setting up alerts for suspicious activities and investigating any potential security breaches.
Implement two-factor authentication to add an additional layer of security. This requires users to provide two forms of identification, typically a password and a physical token or biometric data.

Regularly educate employees about the importance of data security and best practices for protecting sensitive information. This includes training on password management, recognizing phishing attempts, and reporting suspicious activity.

extracted_data.requirement: Use PDCA model for ISMS process
extracted_data.requirement_description: The organization must base its Information Security Management System (ISMS) process on the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) model.

controls.control: Develop a formal, documented PDCA (Plan-Do-Check-Act) process for the ISMS. This includes defining the scope of the ISMS, establishing policies, procedures, and objectives, and documenting them.

controls.control_title: Assign responsibilities for PDCA process implementation
controls.control: Designate specific roles and responsibilities within the organization for the implementation and maintenance of the PDCA process. This includes identifying a PDCA process owner, team members, and any necessary external resources.

controls.control_title: Plan phase: Define objectives and plan actions
controls.control: In the planning phase, establish measurable objectives for the ISMS, identify required resources, and outline the steps to achieve these objectives. This includes risk assessments, identifying legal and regulatory requirements, and defining policies and procedures.

controls.control_title: Do phase: Implement actions and monitor performance
controls.control: In the doing phase, execute the planned actions, monitor their progress, and make any necessary adjustments. This includes training staff, deploying security controls, and conducting regular audits.

controls.control_title: Check phase: Review and evaluate performance
controls.control: In the checking phase, review the effectiveness of the implemented actions against the established objectives. This includes conducting internal audits, management reviews, and corrective action processes.

controls.control_title: Act phase: Take corrective action if necessary
controls.control: In the acting phase, take any necessary corrective actions to address nonconformities or areas for improvement identified during the checking phase. This includes updating policies and procedures, re-training staff, and making adjustments to the ISMS as needed.

4.2 Establishing and managing the ISMS 
4.2.1 Establish the ISMS 
The organization shall do the following. 
a) Define the scope and boundaries of the ISMS in terms of the characteristics of the business, the 
organization, its location, assets and technology, and including details of and justification for any 
exclusions from the scope (see 1.2). 
b) Define an ISMS policy in terms of the characteristics of the business, the organization, its location, assets 
and technology that: 
1) includes a framework for setting objectives and establishes an overall sense of direction and 
principles for action with regard to information security; 
2) takes into account business and legal or regulatory requirements, and contractual security 
obligations; 
3) aligns with the organization’s strategic risk management context in which the establishment and 
maintenance of the ISMS will take place; 
4) establishes criteria against which risk will be evaluated (see 4.2.1c)); and 
5) has been approved by management. 
NOTE:  For the purposes of this International Standard, the ISMS policy is considered as a superset of the 
information security policy. These policies can be described in one document. 
c) Define the risk assessment approach of the organization. 
1) Identify a risk assessment methodology that is suited to the ISMS, and the identified business 
information security, legal and regulatory requirements.  
2) Develop criteria for accepting risks and identify the acceptable levels of risk. (see 5.1f)). 
The risk assessment methodology selected shall ensure that risk assessments produce comparable and 
reproducible results. 
NOTE:  There are different methodologies for risk assessment. Examples of risk assessment methodologies are 
discussed in ISO/IEC TR 13335-3, Information technology — Guidelines for the management of IT Security — 
Techniques for the management of IT Security.

controls.control_title: Verify User Identity before Granting Property Access
controls.control: Implement a robust user authentication system to ensure that only verified and authenticated users can access property-related information or actions. This includes multi-factor authentication, strong password policies, and regular account security checks.

controls.control_title: Clearly Define User Roles and Permissions

4.2.2 Implement and operate the ISMS 
The organization shall do the following. 
a) Formulate a risk treatment plan that identifies the appropriate management action, resources, 
responsibilities and priorities for managing information security risks (see 5). 
b) Implement the risk treatment plan in order to achieve the identified control objectives, which includes 
consideration of funding and allocation of roles and responsibilities. 
c) Implement controls selected in 4.2.1g) to meet the control objectives. 
d) Define how to measure the effectiveness of the selected controls or groups of controls and specify how 
these measurements are to be used to assess control effectiveness to produce comparable and 
reproducible results (see 4.2.3c)). 
NOTE:  Measuring the effectiveness of controls allows managers and staff to determine how well controls achieve 
planned control objectives. 
e) Implement training and awareness programmes (see 5.2.2). 
f) Manage operation of the ISMS. 
g) Manage resources for the ISMS (see 5.2). 
h) Implement procedures and other controls capable of enabling prompt detection of security events and 
response to security incidents (see 4.2.3a)). 
4.2.3 Monitor and review the ISMS 
The organization shall do the following. 
a) Execute monitoring and reviewing procedures and other controls to: 
1) promptly detect errors in the results of processing; 
2) promptly identify attempted and successful security breaches and incidents; 
3) enable management to determine whether the security activities delegated to people or implemented 
by information technology are performing as expected;  
4) help detect security events and thereby prevent security incidents by the use of indicators; and 
5) determine whether the actions taken to resolve a breach of security were effective. 
b) Undertake regular reviews of the effectiveness of the ISMS (including meeting ISMS policy and 
objectives, and review of security controls) taking into account results of security audits, incidents, results 
from effectiveness measurements, suggestions and feedback from all interested parties. 
c) Measure the effectiveness of controls to verify that security requirements have been met. 
d) Review risk assessments at planned intervals and review the residual risks and the identified acceptable 
levels of risks, taking into account changes to: 
1) the organization; 
2) technology;

4.2.4 Maintain and improve the ISMS  
The organization shall regularly do the following. 
a) Implement the identified improvements in the ISMS. 
b) Take appropriate corrective and preventive actions in accordance with 8.2 and 8.3. Apply the lessons 
learnt from the security experiences of other organizations and those of the organization itself. 
c) Communicate the actions and improvements to all interested parties with a level of detail appropriate to 
the circumstances and, as relevant, agree on how to proceed. 
d) Ensure that the improvements achieve their intended objectives. 
4.3 Documentation requirements 
4.3.1 General 
Documentation shall include records of management decisions, ensure that actions are traceable to 
management decisions and policies, and ensure that the recorded results are reproducible. 
It is important to be able to demonstrate the relationship from the selected controls back to the results of the 
risk assessment and risk treatment process, and subsequently back to the ISMS policy and objectives.  
The ISMS documentation shall include: 
a) documented statements of the ISMS policy (see 4.2.1b)) and objectives; 
b) the scope of the ISMS (see 4.2.1a)); 
c) procedures and controls in support of the ISMS; 
d) a description of the risk assessment methodology (see 4.2.1c)); 
e) the risk assessment report (see 4.2.1c) to 4.2.1g)); 
f) the risk treatment plan (see 4.2.2b));

g) documented procedures needed by the organization to ensure the effective planning, operation and 
control of its information security processes and describe how to measure the effectiveness of controls 
(see 4.2.3c)); 
h) records required by this International Standard (see 4.3.3); and 
i) the Statement of Applicability. 
NOTE 1: Where the term “documented procedure” appears within this International Standard, this means that the 
procedure is established, documented, implemented and maintained. 
NOTE 2: The extent of the ISMS documentation can differ from one organization to another owing to: 
- the size of the organization and the type of its activities; and 
- the scope and complexity of the security requirements and the system being managed. 
NOTE 3: Documents and records may be in any form or type of medium. 
4.3.2 Control of documents 
Documents required by the ISMS shall be protected and controlled. A documented procedure shall be 
established to define the management actions needed to: 
a) approve documents for adequacy prior to issue; 
b) review and update documents as necessary and re-approve documents; 
c) ensure that changes and the current revision status of documents are identified; 
d) ensure that relevant versions of applicable documents are available at points of use; 
e) ensure that documents remain legible and readily identifiable; 
f) ensure that documents are available to those who need them, and are transferred, stored and ultimately 
disposed of in accordance with the procedures applicable to their classification; 
g) ensure that documents of external origin are identified; 
h) ensure that the distribution of documents is controlled; 
i) prevent the unintended use of obsolete documents; and 
j) apply suitable identification to them if they are retained for any purpose. 
4.3.3 Control of records 
Records shall be established and maintained to provide evidence of conformity to requirements and the 
effective operation of the ISMS. They shall be protected and controlled. The ISMS shall take account of any 
relevant legal or regulatory requirements and contractual obligations. Records shall remain legible, readily 
identifiable and retrievable. The controls needed for the identification, storage, protection, retrieval, retention 
time and disposition of records shall be documented and implemented.

6 Internal ISMS audits 
The organization shall conduct internal ISMS audits at planned intervals to determine whether the control 
objectives, controls, processes and procedures of its ISMS: 
a) conform to the requirements of this International Standard and relevant legislation or regulations; 
b) conform to the identified information security requirements; 
c) are effectively implemented and maintained; and 
d) perform as expected. 
An audit programme shall be planned, taking into consideration the status and importance of the processes 
and areas to be audited, as well as the results of previous audits. The audit criteria, scope, frequency and 
methods shall be defined. The selection of auditors and conduct of audits shall ensure objectivity and 
impartiality of the audit process. Auditors shall not audit their own work. 
The responsibilities and requirements for planning and conducting audits, and for reporting results and 
maintaining records (see 4.3.3) shall be defined in a documented procedure. 
The management responsible for the area being audited shall ensure that actions are taken without undue 
delay to eliminate detected nonconformities and their causes. Follow-up activities shall include the verification 
of the actions taken and the reporting of verification results (see 8). 
NOTE: ISO 19011:2002, Guidelines for quality and/or environmental management systems auditing , may provide 
helpful guidance for carrying out the internal ISMS audits. 
7 Management review of the ISMS 
7.1 General 
Management shall review the organization’s ISMS at planned intervals (at least once a year) to ensure its 
continuing suitability, adequacy and effectiveness. This review shall include assessing opportunities for 
improvement and the need for changes to the ISMS, including the information security policy and information 
security objectives. The results of the reviews shall be clearly documented and records shall be maintained 
(see 4.3.3). 
7.2 Review input 
The input to a management review shall include: 
a) results of ISMS audits and reviews; 
b) feedback from interested parties; 
c) techniques, products or procedures, which could be used in the organization to improve the ISMS 
performance and effectiveness; 
d) status of preventive and corrective actions; 
e) vulnerabilities or threats not adequately addressed in the previous risk assessment; 
f) results from effectiveness measurements;

extracted_data.requirement_description: Regular audits are necessary to ensure that the ISMS is functioning as intended, conforming to relevant standards and regulations, and addressing any identified information security requirements.

Provide regular training to the internal audit team on the latest ISMS standards, methodologies, and best practices. This will ensure that they have the necessary skills and knowledge to effectively conduct audits.

Establish a process for reporting audit findings, recommendations, and corrective actions. Ensure that there is a mechanism in place to track the progress of these actions and verify their implementation.

Maintain proper documentation of all internal ISMS audits, including audit reports, findings, recommendations, corrective actions, and their outcomes. Store these documents securely and make them available for review as needed.

7.3 Review output 
The output from the management review shall include any decisions and actions related to the following. 
a) Improvement of the effectiveness of the ISMS. 
b) Update of the risk assessment and risk treatment plan. 
c) Modification of procedures and controls that effect information security, as necessary, to respond to 
internal or external events that may impact on the ISMS, including changes to: 
1) business requirements; 
2) security requirements; 
3) business processes effecting the existing business requirements; 
4) regulatory or legal requirements; 
5) contractual obligations; and 
6) levels of risk and/or criteria for accepting risks. 
d) Resource needs. 
e) Improvement to how the effectiveness of controls is being measured. 
8 ISMS improvement 
8.1 Continual improvement 
The organization shall continually improve the effectiveness of the ISMS through the use of the information 
security policy, information security objectives, audit results, analysis of monitored events, corrective and 
preventive actions and management review (see 7). 
8.2 Corrective action 
The organization shall take action to eliminate the cause of nonconformities with the ISMS requirements in 
order to prevent recurrence. The documented procedure for corrective action shall define requirements for: 
a) identifying nonconformities; 
b) determining the causes of nonconformities; 
c) evaluating the need for actions to ensure that nonconformities do not recur; 
d) determining and implementing the corrective action needed; 
e) recording results of action taken (see 4.3.3); and 
f) reviewing of corrective action taken.

controls.control_title: Regular Review of Information Security Policy

The review should cover all sections of the policy to ensure they are still relevant, up-to-date, and effective in addressing current and future risks.

An approval and signature process should be established for the information security policy. This ensures that all stakeholders are aware of their responsibilities and have agreed to comply with the policy. The policy should also include a review and update schedule, signed by the appropriate parties.

A training and awareness program should be developed to educate employees about the organization's information security policy. This program should include regular refresher courses, quizzes, and reminders to ensure that all employees are aware of their responsibilities and the consequences of non-compliance.

A feedback mechanism should be established to allow employees, contractors, and other stakeholders to provide suggestions or report issues related to the information security policy. This feedback can help improve the policy and ensure it remains effective.

controls.control_title: Establish Incident Response Plan for External Party Breaches

extracted_data.requirement: Maintain an inventory of all important assets
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that the organization keeps track of its valuable assets for proper protection.

controls.control: Establish and implement a centralized Asset Inventory Management System (AIMS) to maintain an up-to-date inventory of all important assets. The system should include details such as asset name, location, owner, purchase date, warranty information, and depreciation schedule.
Implement a regular schedule for updating the asset inventory in the AIMS. This could be weekly, bi-weekly, or monthly, depending on the organization's needs.
Label and tag all important assets with a unique identifier. This will facilitate easy identification and tracking of assets within the inventory.
Document a clear procedure for disposing of assets that are no longer in use. This should include steps for data sanitization, asset decommissioning, and proper disposal methods.
Periodically conduct audits of the asset inventory to ensure its accuracy and completeness. Any discrepancies should be investigated and resolved promptly.

controls.control_title: Define and document security roles and responsibilities

controls.control_title: Establish a process for onboarding and offboarding roles
controls.control: Create a standardized process for granting and revoking access rights when personnel join or leave the organization, minimizing potential security risks during these transitions.

controls.control_title: Immediate Access Revocation upon Employment Termination or Change
controls.control: Upon termination of employment, contract, or third-party agreement, all access rights to company systems, networks, and data should be immediately revoked. This includes but is not limited to: email accounts, VPN access, file shares, and any other resources that require authentication.
Implement a process to verify that all access rights have been successfully revoked within a specified timeframe (e.g., 48 hours) after the termination or change event.

Establish a procedure for notifying employees, contractors, and third-party users about the revocation of their access rights upon termination or change. This notification should be clear, concise, and timely.

Maintain documentation of all access revocations for auditing and compliance purposes. This documentation should include the reason for revocation, the individual affected, and the date of revocation.

controls.control_title: Immediate Access Rights Revocation upon Employee Termination
controls.control: Upon termination of an employee, all access rights to company systems, networks, and data should be immediately revoked. This includes but is not limited to: email accounts, VPN access, network shares, and any other system or application where the employee had access.
Regularly verify that all terminated employees no longer have access to company systems, networks, and data. This should be done immediately after termination and at least once a month thereafter.

In cases where an employee's access rights need to be temporarily reassigned to another employee during the termination process, ensure that these temporary access rights are promptly revoked once the task is completed.
Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of who has access to company systems, networks, and data. This documentation should be regularly reviewed and updated.
Notify the employee's manager or supervisor whenever an employee's access rights are revoked, to ensure that they are aware of any changes and can adjust their work processes accordingly.

controls.control: Maintain a detailed log of all access changes made to the system, including who made the change, what was changed, and when it was changed. This log should be regularly audited.
Establish a regular review process for user access rights to ensure that they are still necessary and appropriate. This process should include the removal of unused or unnecessary access rights.
Ensure that each user only has the minimum level of access necessary to perform their job functions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access or data breaches.
Require approval for any changes to user access rights, especially for sensitive areas of the system. This helps ensure that only authorized personnel can make such changes.
Implement RBAC to simplify access management by assigning users to roles with predefined access rights. This can help ensure consistency and reduce the risk of errors.

controls.control: Implement an Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) system to provide backup power during utility failures. The UPS should be capable of supporting all critical equipment for a minimum of 2 hours.

Install a generator backup system that can automatically take over in case of power failure. The generator should be capable of providing power to all critical equipment for an extended period (e.g., 8 hours or more).

Ensure that the electrical system is designed with redundancy and diversity to minimize the risk of power disruptions. This may include using multiple feeds from different sources, or having standby generators for each critical load.

Implement a power monitoring and alert system to detect and notify of any power disruptions or irregularities. This system should be capable of sending alerts to relevant personnel via email, SMS, or other means.

Maintain an up-to-date inventory of all off-site equipment and verify its presence at regular intervals.

controls.control_title: Implement Access Control for Off-site Locations
controls.control: Establish access controls, such as keycards or biometrics, to limit access to off-site locations and equipment.

controls.control_title: Encrypt Data Stored on Off-site Equipment
controls.control: Encrypt data stored on off-site equipment to protect sensitive information in case of theft or loss.

controls.control_title: Implement Remote Wipe Capability for Off-site Devices
controls.control: Enable remote wipe capability on all off-site devices to prevent data leakage in case of device theft or loss.

controls.control_title: Train Employees on Secure Handling of Off-site Equipment
controls.control: Provide regular training to employees on secure handling, transportation, and storage of off-site equipment.

procedures

Control

extracted_data.requirement: Check all equipment for sensitive data and licensed software before disposing or reusing it.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures the protection of sensitive information and intellectual property by properly handling equipment containing storage media.

controls.control: Develop and implement a checklist to ensure all equipment is thoroughly checked for sensitive data before disposal or reuse. The checklist should include steps such as: 1) Physical inspection of the device, 2) Verification of software installed on the device, 3) Erasure of all stored data, 4) Confirmation that no removable storage devices are attached, and 5) Documentation of the process.

Conduct regular audits to ensure all software installed on equipment is properly licensed. This includes both purchased and open-source software. If unlicensed software is found, remove it before disposal or reuse.
Maintain an inventory of equipment that can be reused. This will help prevent the accidental disposal of equipment that still has sensitive data or licensed software.

extracted_data.requirement: Do not take equipment, information, or software off-site without prior authorization.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement helps prevent unauthorized access to sensitive data and assets by controlling their removal from the organization's premises.

controls.control: All employees must request authorization from the IT department and/or designated supervisor before taking any equipment, information, or software off-site. The request should include details about the purpose, duration, and security measures to be taken.
Maintain an up-to-date inventory of all equipment, information, and software that leaves the premises. This will help in tracking assets and ensuring their safe return.
Implement appropriate security measures for equipment, information, and software taken off-site, such as encryption, password protection, and physical security measures like locks or secure cases.
Upon the employee's return, verify that all equipment, information, and software have been returned and in good condition. If any items are missing or damaged, initiate an investigation.

extracted_data.requirement: Document, maintain, and distribute operating procedures for all users who require them.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that all users have access to the necessary information to correctly and securely operate the organization's information processing facilities.

controls.control: Create a comprehensive set of operating procedures for all systems, applications, and processes used within the organization. These procedures should include step-by-step instructions, best practices, and any necessary references.
Regularly review and update the operating procedures to ensure they remain accurate, up-to-date, and relevant. This includes incorporating any changes in technology, processes, or regulations.
Establish a process for distributing the operating procedures to all users who require them. This can be done through an internal portal, email, or other appropriate channels.
Require users to acknowledge that they have received and understood the operating procedures. This can be done through an electronic signature or a simple checkbox.

Implement a feedback mechanism for users to provide suggestions, ask questions, or report any issues related to the operating procedures. This will help improve the quality and effectiveness of the procedures over time.

extracted_data.requirement: Implement a change management process for all changes to the organization's information processing facilities and systems.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement helps maintain the integrity and security of the organization's information processing facilities by controlling any changes made.

controls.control: Establish a formal change approval process that requires all changes to be reviewed and approved by designated personnel before implementation. This process should include a change request form, change evaluation, and change authorization.
Develop a standardized procedure for implementing changes, which includes testing the change in a controlled environment before deploying it to production systems.

Maintain accurate and up-to-date documentation of all changes made to the organization's information processing facilities and systems, including the reason for the change, who made the change, when the change was made, and any associated risks or issues.

Implement a process for communicating changes to relevant personnel within the organization, including system administrators, end-users, and other stakeholders. This communication should be timely, clear, and include any necessary instructions or training.

Maintain an audit trail of all changes made to the organization's information processing facilities and systems, including who made the change, when the change was made, what was changed, and any associated results or outcomes.

extracted_data.requirement: Segregate duties and responsibilities to minimize the risk of unauthorized or accidental modifications or misuse of organizational assets.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement helps prevent fraud, errors, and security breaches by separating tasks that could be performed together to gain unauthorized access.

controls.control: Implement a Role-Based Access Control system to ensure that users only have access to the resources and functions necessary for their job roles. This includes limiting the ability to modify or delete critical assets.
Enforce Separation of Duties by ensuring that no single user has the authority to perform all critical tasks. This can be achieved through job rotation, shared responsibilities, or automated checks.
Apply the Least Privilege Principle by granting users the minimum level of access required to perform their job functions. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access or misuse.

Conduct regular audits and reviews of user roles, permissions, and activities to identify any potential segregation of duties issues. This can help ensure that the system remains secure and compliant.

extracted_data.requirement: Separate development, testing, and operational facilities to minimize the risk of unauthorized access or changes to the operational system.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement helps maintain the security and integrity of the organization's operational systems by keeping them separate from development and testing environments.

controls.control_title: Segment Network for Separation of Environments
controls.control: Implement network segmentation to physically and logically separate development, testing, and operational networks. This will prevent unauthorized access or changes from one environment to another.
Implement strict access control policies for each environment. Only authorized personnel should have access to the development, testing, and operational environments.
Conduct regular audits of user access in all environments to ensure that only authorized personnel have access and to detect any unauthorized access or changes.
Regularly backup data from each environment. This will allow for quick recovery in case of any accidental loss, corruption, or unauthorized changes.

extracted_data.requirement: Ensure that the agreed-upon security controls, service definitions, and delivery levels are implemented, operated, and maintained by third parties.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement emphasizes the importance of holding third parties accountable for maintaining the agreed-upon security standards when providing services to the organization.

controls.control: Regularly review and update third-party service contracts to ensure they align with the agreed-upon security controls, service definitions, and delivery levels.
Periodically audit third-party services to verify compliance with the agreed-upon security controls, service definitions, and delivery levels.
Establish a system for continuous monitoring of third-party services to ensure they are operating within the agreed-upon service levels and delivering as expected.
Implement a change management process for third-party services to ensure any changes are properly documented, tested, and approved before implementation.

extracted_data.article_text:
ISO/IEC 27001:2005(E) 
© ISO/IEC 2005 – All rights reserved 19
A.10.2.2 Monitoring and review of 
third party services 
Control 
The services, reports and records provided by the third party shall 
be regularly monitored and reviewed, and audits shall be carried out 
regularly. 
A.10.2.3 Managing changes to third 
party services 
Control 
Changes to the provision of services, including maintaining and 
improving existing information security policies, procedures and 
controls, shall be managed, taking account of the criticality of 
business systems and processes involved and re-assessment of 
risks. 
A.10.3 System planning and acceptance 
Objective: To minimize the risk of systems failures. 
A.10.3.1 Capacity management 
Control 
The use of resources shall be monitored, tuned, and projections 
made of future capacity requirements to ensure the required system 
performance. 
A.10.3.2 System acceptance 
Control 
Acceptance criteria for new information systems, upgrades, and new 
versions shall be established and suitable tests of the system(s) 
carried out during development and prior to acceptance. 
A.10.4 Protection against malicious and mobile code 
Objective: To protect the integrity of software and information. 
A.10.4.1 Controls against malicious 
code 
Control 
Detection, prevention, and recovery controls to protect against 
malicious code and appropriate user awareness procedures shall be 
implemented. 
A.10.4.2 Controls against mobile 
code 
Control 
 Where the use of mobile code is authorized, the configuration shall 
ensure that the authorized mobile code operates according to a 
clearly defined security policy, and unauthorized mobile code shall 
be prevented from executing. 
A.10.5 Back-up 
Objective: To maintain the integrity and availability of information and information processing facilities. 
A.10.5.1 Information back-up 
Control 
Back-up copies of information and software shall be taken and 
tested regularly in accordance with the agreed backup policy.
extracted_data.requirement: Regularly monitor and review services, reports, and records from third parties. Conduct regular audits.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that the organization maintains control over the services provided by external vendors to ensure their integrity and compliance with established policies.

controls.control: Establish a schedule for regular monitoring and review of services, reports, and records from third parties. This includes checking for any deviations from agreed service level agreements, compliance with legal and regulatory requirements, and any security incidents or breaches.

Develop a comprehensive audit plan for third parties, outlining the frequency, scope, and methodology of audits. Ensure that audits are conducted in a timely manner and that findings are addressed promptly.
Review all audit reports from third parties, identify any areas of non-compliance or weaknesses, and take appropriate corrective actions.

Implement a mechanism for receiving, investigating, and responding to complaints or issues related to third parties. This includes ensuring that all complaints are handled in a timely and professional manner.

Regularly evaluate the performance of third parties based on agreed service level agreements, compliance with legal and regulatory requirements, and overall satisfaction. Use this information to make informed decisions about future engagements.

controls.control_title: Change Management Process for Third-Party Services
controls.control: Implement a formal change management process for all third-party services. This process should include approval workflows, impact analysis, and risk assessment before any changes are made.
Establish a system for notifying relevant stakeholders about planned changes to third-party services. This includes IT staff, business units, and potentially end-users.
Maintain detailed documentation of all changes made to third-party services, including the reason for the change, the person who made the change, and the impact on systems and processes.
Regularly review and audit changes made to third-party services to ensure compliance with the change management process and identify any potential issues or risks.

extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that the organization's systems have adequate resources to function effectively.

controls.control: Implement a system monitoring tool that continuously monitors CPU, memory, disk I/O, network traffic, and other relevant resources. Set up alerts for critical thresholds to ensure timely response to potential issues.

Regularly analyze resource usage patterns, identify trends, and forecast future resource requirements. Generate reports for stakeholders to facilitate informed decision-making about system capacity planning.

Implement automation tools that can optimize resource usage based on workload patterns, such as load balancing, auto-scaling, and container orchestration. This helps maintain optimal performance while minimizing waste.
Regularly review and adjust system settings to optimize resource usage. This may include tuning database configurations, web server settings, or operating system parameters.

A.10.6 Network security management 
Objective: To ensure the protection of information in networks and the protection of the supporting infrastructure.

Control

be protected from threats, and to maintain security for the systems 
and applications using the network, including information in transit.

Control 
Security features, service levels, and management requirements of 
all network services shall be identified and included in any network 
services agreement, whether these services are provided in-house 
or outsourced.

Objective: To prevent unauthorized disclosure, modification, removal or destruction of assets, and interruption to 
business activities.  
A.10.7.1 Management of removable 
media 
Control 
There shall be procedures in place for the management of 
removable media. 
A.10.7.2 Disposal of media 
Control 
Media shall be disposed of securely and safely when no longer 
required, using formal procedures.  
A.10.7.3 Information handling 
procedures 
Control 
Procedures for the handling and storage of information shall be 
established to protect this information from unauthorized disclosure 
or misuse.  
A.10.7.4 Security of system 
documentation 
Control 
System documentation shall be protected against unauthorized 
access.  
A.10.8 Exchange of information 
Objective: To maintain the security of information and software exchanged within an organization and with any 
external entity. 
A.10.8.1 Information exchange 
policies and procedures 
Control  
Formal exchange policies, procedures, and controls shall be in place 
to protect the exchange of information through the use of all types of 
communication facilities. 
A.10.8.2 Exchange agreements 
Control  
Agreements shall be established for the exchange of information 
and software between the organization and external parties. 
A.10.8.3 Physical media in transit 
Control  
Media containing information shall be protected against 
unauthorized access, misuse or corruption during transportation 
beyond an organization’s physical boundaries.

extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement mandates that organizations protect media containing sensitive information from unauthorized access, misuse, or corruption while in transit beyond their physical premises.

controls.control: All media containing information should be encrypted using strong encryption algorithms before being transported outside the organization's physical boundaries. The encryption keys should be securely managed and protected.
Media should be transported using secure methods such as courier services that provide tracking, tamper-evident seals, and insurance. Personal transportation of media is discouraged.

controls.control_title: Implement multi-factor authentication for sensitive transactions
controls.control: Require users to authenticate using multiple factors, such as a password, a security token, and biometric data, before allowing them to perform sensitive online transactions.

extracted_data.requirement_description: Preventing unauthorized access to sensitive information by ensuring that workspaces are kept clean and secure.

controls.control: Employees must ensure all sensitive documents, papers, and items are securely stored when not in use. This includes but is not limited to: contracts, financial statements, customer information, and company confidential documents.
Employees must log off or lock their workstations when they are away from their desks for more than a few minutes. This includes all electronic devices such as computers, tablets, and smartphones.
All sensitive documents should be stored in secure cabinets or drawers when not in use. These storage areas should be locked at all times and only authorized personnel should have access.
Regular audits of workspaces should be conducted to ensure compliance with the clear desk and screen policies. Non-compliance should be addressed promptly and appropriate corrective actions taken.

Consider using privacy screens on monitors to prevent unauthorized individuals from viewing sensitive information. While this is not a replacement for the clear screen policy, it can provide an additional layer of security.

controls.control_title: Limit Root Access to System Utilities
controls.control: Implement a policy that restricts root access to system utilities, allowing only authorized personnel to execute them. This can be achieved through the use of sudo or similar tools.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Audit System Utility Usage
controls.control: Set up system logging and monitoring tools to track the usage of system utilities. Regularly review these logs for any unusual activity or potential security threats.

controls.control_title: Educate Users on Safe Use of System Utilities

extracted_data.requirement: Implement session time-out
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that idle sessions are terminated to prevent unauthorized access.

controls.control_title: Implement Session Time-out at Application Level
controls.control: Set a session timeout duration within the application code to automatically log out users who have been inactive for a specified period of time. This prevents unauthorized access if a user leaves their device unattended.

controls.control_title: Implement Session Time-out at Network Level (Idle Timeout)
controls.control: Configure network devices such as switches, routers, and firewalls to disconnect idle sessions after a specified period of time. This can help prevent unauthorized access if a user's device is connected but not in use.

controls.control_title: Implement Session Time-out at Operating System Level
controls.control: Configure the operating system of servers and workstations to log off users who have been idle for a specified period of time. This can help conserve resources and prevent unauthorized access if a user is away from their device.

extracted_data.requirement: Restrict information and application system functions access
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that only authorized individuals can access sensitive data and perform specific actions within applications.

controls.control: Define and enforce roles for users, granting access to information and system functions based on job responsibilities. This ensures that only authorized personnel can perform sensitive operations.
Grant users the minimum level of access necessary to perform their job functions, and no more. This reduces the risk of unauthorized access or data breaches.

Periodically review and update user access rights to ensure that they still have a valid business need for the level of access they currently hold. This helps maintain a secure environment by removing unnecessary access.
Require users to provide two or more authentication factors before granting access to the system. This adds an extra layer of security, making it harder for unauthorized users to gain access.
Log all user activities and monitor these logs regularly. This helps detect and respond to potential security incidents, as well as identify any unusual or suspicious activity.

extracted_data.requirement: Isolate sensitive systems
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that sensitive systems are separated from other systems to reduce potential threats and breaches.

controls.control: Configure firewall rules to restrict inbound and outbound traffic for sensitive systems. Allow only necessary ports and IP addresses.
Segment the network using Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs) to isolate sensitive systems from other devices on the same physical network.
Create and enforce Access Control Lists (ACLs) to control access to sensitive systems. This can include IP address-based controls, user-based controls, and role-based controls.
Implement secure remote access solutions for administrators to manage sensitive systems. This can include VPNs, SSH, or RDP with strong authentication and encryption.
Regularly update the operating system and software on sensitive systems to patch known vulnerabilities. This can help prevent unauthorized access or exploitation.

extracted_data.requirement: Develop a policy for mobile computing and communication
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that mobile devices and communications are secured to prevent data breaches when used outside the office.

controls.control: Install and configure a Mobile Device Management (MDM) solution to manage, secure, and monitor all corporate-owned mobile devices. This includes enforcing password policies, remote wipe capabilities, and app management.

Implement secure communication channels for data transmission between mobile devices and corporate networks or cloud services. This includes using Virtual Private Networks (VPN) and encrypted messaging apps.
Require strong passwords for mobile devices, including a minimum length, complexity requirements, and regular changes. Consider implementing multi-factor authentication where possible.
Ensure that all mobile devices are kept up to date with the latest software updates, including operating system and app updates. This helps to patch known vulnerabilities and improve security.
Implement a data backup and recovery solution for mobile devices. Regular backups should be performed, and a recovery plan should be in place in case of data loss.
Encrypt all corporate data stored on mobile devices to protect it from unauthorized access. This includes using full-disk encryption and file-level encryption where possible.

controls.control: Develop a comprehensive telework policy that outlines expectations, responsibilities, and procedures for employees working remotely.

Establish procedures for securing and backing up data, including regular backups and encryption of sensitive information.

Provide necessary equipment, such as laptops and monitors, to employees for effective remote work.

extracted_data.requirement: Specify security requirements for new or enhanced information systems
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that security is considered from the beginning when developing or modifying information systems.

controls.control: Ensure that all users have unique identities and access is granted based on the principle of least privilege. Implement multi-factor authentication for administrative accounts.

controls.control_title: Regular System Updates and Patch Management
controls.control: Establish a process to regularly update and patch all software components, including the operating system, applications, and third-party libraries. This includes applying security patches as soon as they are released.

controls.control_title: Implement Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS)/Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS)
controls.control: Deploy IDS/IPS solutions to monitor network traffic for suspicious activities and alert system administrators. Consider using signature-based, anomaly-based, or behavior-based detection methods.
Configure systems to log all relevant events, such as login attempts, system changes, and user actions. Regularly review these logs for any unusual activity.

controls.control_title: Implement Data Backup and Recovery Procedures
controls.control: Establish a regular backup schedule to ensure data is protected against loss or corruption. Test the recovery process periodically to verify its effectiveness.

A.12.2 Correct processing in applications 
Objective: To prevent errors, loss, unauthorized modification or misuse of information in applications. 
A.12.2.1 Input data validation 
Control 
Data input to applications shall be validated to ensure that this data 
is correct and appropriate. 
A.12.2.2 Control of internal 
processing 
Control 
Validation checks shall be incorporated into applications to detect 
any corruption of information through processing errors or deliberate 
acts. 
A.12.2.3 Message integrity 
Control 
Requirements for ensuring authenticity and protecting message 
integrity in applications shall be identified, and appropriate controls 
identified and implemented. 
A.12.2.4 Output data validation 
Control 
Data output from an application shall be validated to ensure that the 
processing of stored information is correct and appropriate to the 
circumstances. 
A.12.3 Cryptographic controls 
Objective: To protect the confidentiality, authenticity or integrity of information by cryptographic means. 
A.12.3.1 Policy on the use of 
cryptographic controls 
Control 
 A policy on the use of cryptographic controls for protection of 
information shall be developed and implemented. 
A.12.3.2 Key management 
Control 
Key management shall be in place to support the organization’s use 
of cryptographic techniques. 
A.12.4 Security of system files 
Objective: To ensure the security of system files. 
A.12.4.1 Control of operational 
software 
Control 
There shall be procedures in place to control the installation of 
software on operational systems. 
A.12.4.2 Protection of system test 
data 
Control 
Test data shall be selected carefully, and protected and controlled. 
A.12.4.3 Access control to program 
source code 
Control 
Access to program source code shall be restricted.
extracted_data.requirement: Validate input data
extracted_data.requirement_description: Ensure the accuracy and appropriateness of data entered into applications.

controls.control: Implement type checking for all input data to ensure that only expected data types are accepted. This can be done using a library or built-in functions depending on the programming language.
Implement range checking for all input data to ensure that values fall within expected ranges. This can be done using conditional statements or libraries depending on the programming language.
Implement format checking for input data, such as email addresses, phone numbers, and dates. This can be done using regular expressions or libraries depending on the programming language.
Sanitize input data to remove any potentially harmful characters, such as SQL injection attacks. This can be done using libraries or built-in functions depending on the programming language.

controls.control_title: Input Data Validation - Custom Validation Rules
controls.control: Implement custom validation rules based on business requirements. For example, if a password must contain at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, and one number.

controls.control_title: Check for missing or incomplete data

controls.control_title: Implement error handling for invalid data

extracted_data.requirement_description: Implement measures to protect the authenticity and integrity of messages within applications.

controls.control: Implement a message hashing mechanism such as SHA-256 or MD5 to ensure the integrity of messages. This can be done by generating a hash value for each message and comparing it with the received message's hash value.
Use secure transport layers like SSL/TLS to encrypt messages during transmission. This ensures that the message is not tampered with during transit.
Add timestamps to each message for verification purposes. If a message arrives out of order or significantly delayed, it may indicate tampering or corruption.

controls.control_title: Regular Audit Logs for Source Code Repositories

extracted_data.requirement: Implement formal change control procedures
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that any changes made to application system software and information are managed in a structured and controlled manner, reducing the risk of errors or security vulnerabilities.

controls.control: Establish a formal change request process that requires all changes to be documented, reviewed, and approved before implementation. This process should include change categories (e.g., standard, major, emergency), change owners, and change approval authorities.

Implement a workflow for change approvals that ensures all changes are reviewed by the appropriate personnel before implementation. This workflow should include steps such as review, approval, and rejection, with clear communication channels for each step.

Perform a thorough impact analysis for each change request to understand the potential effects on the system, data, and business operations. This analysis should consider factors such as system downtime, data integrity, and user experience.

Maintain accurate documentation for all changes, including the change request, approval process, implementation details, and post-implementation review. This documentation should be easily accessible to relevant personnel and auditors.

Provide training for all personnel involved in the change process, ensuring they understand their roles and responsibilities. This training should cover topics such as the change request process, impact analysis, and documentation requirements.

controls.control: Formally establish an Audit Committee consisting of senior management and independent directors. The committee should be responsible for overseeing the organization's annual audit, as well as reviewing and approving the audit plan.

The principles given in the OECD Guidelines for the Security of Information Systems and Networks apply to all 
policy and operational levels that govern the security of information systems and networks. This International 
Standard provides an information security management system framework for implementing some of the 
OECD principles using the PDCA model and the processes described in Clauses 4, 5, 6 and 8, as indicated in 
Table B.1.

OECD principle Corresponding ISMS process and PDCA phase 
Awareness 
Participants should be aware of the need for security of 
information systems and networks and what they can do 
to enhance security. 
This activity is part of the Do phase (see 4.2.2 and 5.2.2). 
Responsibility 
All participants are responsible for the security of 
information systems and networks. 
This activity is part of the Do phase (see 4.2.2 and 5.1). 
Response 
Participants should act in a timely and co-operative 
manner to prevent, detect and respond to security 
incidents. 
This is in part a monitoring activity Check phase (see 
4.2.3 and 6 to 7.3) and a responding activity Act phase 
(see 4.2.4 and 8.1 to 8.3). This can also be covered by 
some aspects of the Plan and Check phases. 
Risk assessment 
Participants should conduct risk assessments. 
This activity is part of the Plan phase (see 4.2.1) and risk 
reassessment is part of the Check phase (see 4.2.3 and 6 
to 7.3). 
Security design and implementation 
Participants should incorporate security as an essential 
element of information systems and networks. 
Once a risk assessment has been completed, controls are 
selected for the treatment of risks as part of the Plan 
phase (see 4.2.1). The Do phase (see 4.2.2 and 5.2) then 
covers the implementation and operational use of these 
controls.

encompassed in the Plan, Do, Check and Act phases.

Participants should review and reassess the security of 
information systems and networks, and make 
appropriate modifications to security policies, practices,

controls.control: Define the boundaries of the Information Security Management System (ISMS) in terms of locations, systems, personnel, and processes. Document this definition in an ISMS Scope Statement.

controls.control_title: Develop and implement an ISMS policy

Develop a documented process for responding to and managing information security incidents, including identification, containment, eradication, recovery, and lessons learned.
Perform periodic risk assessments to identify potential threats, vulnerabilities, and risks to the ISMS, and develop plans to mitigate these risks.

controls.control: The organization shall establish, document, and make available for access to all personnel, a quality policy that includes a commitment to meeting customer requirements and continually improving the effectiveness of the QMS.

controls.control: The organization shall establish, document, and maintain a quality manual describing the overall structure, processes, and resources of the QMS.

controls.control_title: Establish and maintain a documented procedure for control of nonconforming product
controls.control: The organization shall establish and maintain a documented procedure for controlling nonconforming product, to prevent its inadvertent use or delivery.

extracted_data.requirement: Implement an Information and Communications Technology Security Management System as per ISO/IEC 13335-1:2004 and related guidelines
extracted_data.requirement_description: The organization must establish, implement, maintain, and continually improve a documented information and communications technology security management system in accordance with the concepts and models provided in ISO/IEC 13335-1:2004, as well as the techniques outlined in ISO/IEC TR 13335-3:1998 and ISO/IEC TR 13335-4:2000.

controls.control: Develop, document, and implement a comprehensive security policy that outlines the organization's approach to information security. The policy should cover areas such as asset protection, access control, incident management, and business continuity.

Perform regular risk assessments to identify potential vulnerabilities and threats to the organization's information assets. The results of these assessments should be used to prioritize security measures and allocate resources effectively.

Implement a robust access control system to ensure that only authorized individuals can access sensitive information. This includes setting up user accounts, password policies, and role-based access controls.

Establish procedures for handling security incidents, including detection, analysis, containment, recovery, and post-incident review. These processes should be documented and communicated to all relevant staff.

Provide regular security awareness training to all employees to ensure they understand the importance of information security and their role in maintaining it. This could include topics such as phishing, password management, and safe use of technology.

extracted_data.requirement: Adopt an Environmental Management System as per ISO 14001:2004
extracted_data.requirement_description: The organization must establish, implement, maintain, and continually improve a documented environmental management system in accordance with the requirements of ISO 14001:2004.

controls.control: Develop and implement an environmental policy that outlines the organization's commitment to sustainable practices, compliance with ISO 14001:2004, and specific environmental objectives.
Identify all significant environmental aspects and impacts associated with the organization's operations, products, or services.
Set measurable environmental objectives and targets to be achieved within a specified timeframe, based on the identified significant environmental aspects and impacts.
Develop, implement, maintain, and continually improve an environmental management system that includes all necessary elements as per ISO 14001:2004.
Provide training to employees on the environmental policy, procedures, and their roles in maintaining compliance with ISO 14001:2004.
Maintain documentation of the environmental management system, including procedures, records, and reports, to demonstrate compliance with ISO 14001:2004.

Conduct internal audits of the environmental management system at planned intervals to evaluate its conformance with ISO 14001:2004, and hold regular management reviews to ensure continual improvement.

extracted_data.requirement: Implement an Information Security Incident Management process as per ISO/IEC TR 18044:2004
extracted_data.requirement_description: The organization must establish and maintain a documented information security incident management process in accordance with the guidelines provided in ISO/IEC TR 18044:2004.

controls.control: Create a dedicated team responsible for managing security incidents, including incident handling, communication, and reporting. The team should consist of representatives from various departments such as IT, Legal, HR, and Management.
Create a comprehensive incident response plan that outlines the steps to be taken during an incident, including identification, containment, eradication, recovery, and lessons learned.
Establish clear procedures for reporting security incidents, ensuring that all employees know how to report an incident and the importance of doing so promptly.

Keep detailed logs of all security incidents, including their nature, impact, resolution steps taken, and any follow-up actions required. These logs should be regularly reviewed to identify trends and areas for improvement.
Provide regular training to the incident management team and other relevant staff on incident response procedures, ensuring they are familiar with their roles and responsibilities during an incident.

extracted_data.requirement: Perform quality and/or environmental management systems auditing as per ISO 19011:2002, ISO/IEC Guide 62:1996, and ISO/IEC Guide 73:2002
extracted_data.requirement_description: The organization must perform quality and/or environmental management systems auditing in accordance with the guidelines provided in ISO 19011:2002, ISO/IEC Guide 62:1996, and ISO/IEC Guide 73:2002.

controls.control: Develop and implement a documented audit program that outlines the frequency, scope, and objectives of audits in accordance with ISO 19011:2002.
Provide training to auditors on the requirements of ISO 19011:2002, ISO/IEC Guide 62:1996, and ISO/IEC Guide 73:2002, as well as audit techniques and procedures.
Create checklists for each type of audit (quality, environmental) based on the requirements of the relevant standards and guidelines.
Perform necessary pre-audit activities such as planning, communication with the auditee, and gathering of required information.
Prepare a report detailing the audit findings, including nonconformities, opportunities for improvement, and recommendations. Ensure that the report is clear, concise, and objective.
Implement a system to track and follow up on audit findings to ensure corrective actions are taken in a timely manner.
